procedure.title: Pest Management in Food Manufacturing, Processing, and Storage Facilities
procedure.goal: To establish and execute an Integrated Pest Management (IPM) program to control pests in food-related facilities while minimizing health, economic, and environmental hazards.

steps.action: Establish a preventive pest management program
steps.note: This involves integrating building design, grounds maintenance, and sanitation.
Eliminate litter, keep grass short, ensure proper drainage, and position lighting away from buildings to reduce pest harborage.
Seal cracks, screen windows, use tight-fitting doors, and eliminate voids where pests can live.

steps.action: Establish an in-plant sanitation inspection program
steps.note: Requires forming a committee, setting goals, and getting support from all personnel.
Focus on obscure places, incoming materials, and warehouse storage. Record all defects.
Assign realistic correction dates and follow up to ensure completion.
This is a key component of IPM to detect pests early.
Place traps in a grid pattern or in high-risk areas and map their locations.
Look for trends and increases in pest numbers to pinpoint infestations and evaluate control measures.

steps.action: Perform a crack and crevice treatment
conditions: This is the only type of residual application permitted in food areas.
steps.note: Apply small amounts of insecticide into cracks, voids, and joints.

steps.note: Involves application to broad surfaces like walls and floors.

Involves sanitation, exclusion, trapping, and baiting.

steps.action: Place and maintain rodent bait stations
steps.note: Place stations along walls and runways where rodent activity is observed.
Place traps along walls and in concealed areas. Use numerous traps for mice.
Ensure carriers like trucks and boxcars are clean and free of infestation.

constraints.text: Always read and follow the pesticide label. Use of a pesticide in a manner inconsistent with its labeling is illegal.
Pesticides should be used as a last resort within an Integrated Pest Management (IPM) program.
Wear appropriate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), including NIOSH-approved respirators, as specified by the label.
In warehouses, maintain an 18-inch space between pallets and walls to allow for inspection.
A food product containing an unapproved pesticide or a residue above the tolerance level is considered adulterated and must be destroyed.
For rodent-proofing, seal all openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice and 1/2 inch for rats.
In federally inspected meat plants, pesticides must be on a USDA-approved list.
